Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Deciphering functionality of mutations across the human genome with respect to parental DNA contribution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Every human genome consists of approximately 6.5 billion deoxyribose nucleic acid (DNA) bases organized into two sets of 23 chromosomes. Each individual receives one haploid set of chromosomes (n=23 chromosomes, ~3 billion DNA bases) from their mother and one set from their father upon fertilization, making a diploid genome. More effective methods accounting for diploid genome could help elucidate genome function and missing genome heritability in a number of genomic sub-disciplines including clinical genome annotation and complex disease studies. In collaboration with Dr. Ken Wing-Kin Sung at the National University of Singapore who has expertise in computational genomics, this research project will develop computational methods to uncover features dependent on the diploid nature of the human genome.

Human genome sequencing technologies have rapidly advanced in recent years. However, accurate statistical and computational methods are needed to assign maternal or paternal specific (phase) function to individual mutations. Sequence analyses that take into account the phase-specific context of each variant by leveraging familial trios may uncover the functional effects of mutation combinations that would otherwise go undetected. The goal of this project is to provide a modular phase computational pipeline that can be adapted for datasets of sequenced trios, thus datasets where nuclear trios and extended pedigrees have been sequenced will be incorporated into this study. Currently, a preliminary 'functional phase' pipeline to analyze samples has been implemented in the programming languages Python and R. This early stage software has already uncovered novel insights regarding the frequency of phase-specific functional coding pairs and statistical determination of functional variants alleles in the available dataset. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project entitled "Deciphering functionality of mutations across the human genome with respect to parental contribution of DNA" was hosted by associate professor Dr. Ken Wing-Kin Sung, at the Genome Institute of Singapore. The Intellectual Merit of the research project aimed to understand the distribution of naturally occurring variants, or DNA mutations, that occur within a human individual to influence each of the two chromosome homologous in each of the 20,000+ genes humans possess. In this context, it is important to remember that humans have two copies of their genome, one maternal copy and one paternal copy. Thus, combinations of variants, acting either in cis (i.e., present on the same chromosomal gene homolog) or in trans (i.e., on opposite chromosomal gene homologs) are likely to influence gene function, but identifying such combinations is not trivial, for two reasons: 1. Phase information (i.e., separation of the nucleotide content of each gene homolog) is required; and 2.

The methodology generated compared the frequencies of phased alleles and the computationally predicted functional annotations across those affected by neuropsychiatric disorders such as bipolar disorder. This information is of crucial importance for advancing biological insight into complete the human genome because the inability to consider the natural redundancy in biological processing could be problematic for a number of reasons. Additionally, the findings attempted to reconcile the functional implications of these 'diploid' variations across the genome to elucidate mechanisms of disease. A strategy for identifying variant combinations that have functional significance in cis vs. in trans is required that accommodates variants that act independently and not in a phase-specific manner. At the Genome Institute of Singapore, I was able to examine the propensity of phased alleles to occur with in the genome of individuals, and then to asses their biological functionality using methods to annotate the human genome in a study that consisted of parent-offspring trios where whole-genome sequencing had been performed (N=33). The study findings suggest that there are a significant distribution of both cis and trans phased alleles within the genome, however the contribution of these variants toward neuropsychiatric pathogenesis has yet to be elucidated.

Broader impacts of the EAPSI fellowship included a first-hand research experience in Singapore where I was able to explore the scientific community at the National University of Singapore in addition to the interaction of Chinese, Malaysian, and Indian heritage present; developed further the skills pertaining to the biological interpretation of the genome in addition to whole genome annotation methods; and an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure. I feel that I was able to meet the NSF primary objective to foster and experience international collaborations early in my career, which is an experience that will easily benefit me throughout my career in science no matter the nature of the position I may hold. The investigators program of research and current projects were disseminated through presentations in Singapore as well as conferences in the U.S., in addition to being written up in a manuscript detailing the diploid genome findings. Thank you to all who made the experience possible.
